title: 104_hr3447
content: The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996, also known as the Act, aims to hold Members of Congress accountable for breaching the public trust. It states that Members of Congress who are convicted of a felony should not receive taxpayer-funded retirement benefits. The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996 amended Section 8312(a) of title 5, United States Code to include that Members of Congress convicted of a felony after the enactment of the Act should not receive taxpayer-funded retirement benefits. The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996 amended Section 8312 of title 5, United States Code to define offenses for which Members of Congress convicted of a felony after becoming a Member should not receive taxpayer-funded retirement benefits. The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996 amended Section 8312 of title 5, United States Code to specify that Members of Congress convicted of a felony after becoming a Member should not receive taxpayer-funded retirement benefits if the offense was committed on or after the enactment of the Act. The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996 amended Section 8313(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code to include forfeiture of contributions and deposits for offenses described in section 8312(e). The Congressional Pension Integrity Act of 1996 amended Section 8313(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code to include forfeiture of contributions and deposits for offenses described in section 8312(e). Section 8316 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to restrict refunds for individuals convicted of offenses under section 8312(e) and to specify treatment of contributions to the Thrift Savings Plan. When annuity or retired pay is denied due to certain offenses, the individual's Thrift Savings Plan credit can be refunded upon application, as per regulations set by the Executive Director. Refunds are not available for offenses specified in section 8312(e). The Thrift Savings Plan credit can be refunded if annuity or retired pay is denied due to specific offenses, as per regulations set by the Executive Director. Refunds are not available for offenses listed in section 8312(e).
